awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Integrating MentorAI into a student success platform
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader/commercial impact of this SBIR Phase I project addresses the critical need for scalable, personalized student support in higher education. The project will develop an artificial intelligence (AI)-assisted mentoring platform that enhances peer mentoring programs through data-informed, evidence-based guidance. This innovation comes at a crucial time, as student distress rates have doubled over the past decade, and institutions struggle to meet growing demands for mental health and academic support. The technology will particularly benefit underrepresented students, who often face barriers accessing traditional support services. By combining AI capabilities with human peer mentors, this innovation will make technical advances in how to leverage AI tools within the context of human interactions. This will enable institutions to affordably scale high-quality, site-specific support services that improve student retention and success, advancing the health and wellbeing, academic achievement, and economic prosperity of marginalized students. The commercial potential is significant, with the mentoring software market projected to reach $1.3 billion by 2027. The platform's unique integration of data-driven insights with affordably scaled peer mentoring creates a competitive advantage in this growing market. The business model focuses initially on higher education institutions, with potential expansion into nonprofit, government, and professional development sectors. This product enhancement will offer unique features that address growing demands for personalized, evidence-based support. 

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will develop and validate an innovative integration of large language models with retrieval-augmented generation technology to enhance peer mentoring effectiveness. The research addresses technical challenges in secure data integration, model fine-tuning, and scalable system architecture. The project will implement advanced encryption methods and differential privacy techniques to protect sensitive student information while enabling real-time, personalized support. The system architecture employs a modular, multi-tenant design that allows customization for specific institutional contexts while maintaining response times below 500 milliseconds. The research methodology includes developing secure protocols for data integration, implementing bias detection algorithms, and creating a comprehensive ethical framework for a "trustworthy knowledge-in-the-loop" approach using Retrieval-Augmented Generation technology to ensure accurate and evidence-based responses. Technical objectives include achieving 90% accuracy in contextually relevant responses and 85% user satisfaction ratings. The anticipated results include a fully operational prototype demonstrating secure integration of multiple data sources, personalized recommendation generation, and scalable performance under peak usage conditions

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
NSF SBIR Phase I Project Outcomes Report

Project Title:

MentorAI: Integrating MentorAI into a student success platform

NSF SBIR Award Number:

Award 2450833

Principal Investigator:

Nancy McNamara, MentorPRO, LLC

Summary of Project Outcomes:

During our NSF SBIR Phase I project, we successfully developed MentorAI, an innovative AI assistant that enhances college mentoring programs by delivering personalized support directly to mentors. Integrated into MentorPRO’s established student mentoring platform, MentorAI leverages advanced artificial intelligence technology to provide concise, real-time mentee summaries and expert, personalized advice based on individual student data and campus resources.

The core innovation behind MentorAI is a carefully engineered combination of an expert-trained Large Language Model (LLM) and Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG). Specifically, MentorAI synthesizes individual mentee information (such as challenges, goals, surveys, and interactions), institutional resources, evidence-based best practices, and publicly available information. These elements are dynamically integrated to ensure responses are accurate, contextually relevant, and tailored specifically to each student’s unique needs and institutional context.

A significant technical achievement was the secure integration of MentorAI into a multi-tenant, cloud-based SaaS platform. This required rigorous testing and implementation of robust data privacy protocols, secure APIs, and compliance measures aligned with FERPA and data privacy standards. Each participating institution has a dedicated, isolated data environment, effectively preventing data leakage and ensuring privacy and security.

During Phase I, we rigorously tested multiple AI models to address response latency. After systematic evaluations considering both speed and accuracy, we selected GPT-3.5 Turbo as the optimal model. This choice improved MentorAI’s response times significantly, ensuring timely and efficient interactions in real mentoring contexts.

Extensive user testing, including surveys, interviews, and focus groups conducted at UMass Boston, validated MentorAI’s value. Mentors found it particularly useful for reducing cognitive load, streamlining resource identification, and enhancing their capacity to deliver personalized support. Students strongly favored transparency regarding AI assistance, prompting thoughtful design revisions that allow MentorAI to support mentors without replacing their authentic voice. This "human-in-the-loop" design was widely praised for preserving meaningful, genuine mentor-student interactions.

Importantly, the project highlighted significant institutional demand. Over 45 institutions have already adopted the MentorPRO platform, and there is strong market interest for MentorAI’s scalable solution to common mentoring program challenges such as limited mentor resources and inconsistent support. Additionally, Professor Jean Rhodes and the team produced an expert-informed training guide, embedding decades of peer-reviewed mentoring, coaching, and student-support research directly into MentorAI’s logic. This evidence-based approach clearly distinguishes MentorAI from existing mentoring solutions and student-facing chatbots.

Phase I also positioned us effectively for Phase II commercialization efforts and expanded evaluations. We are participating in NSF’s Innovation Corps (I-Corps) program, refining our understanding of MentorAI’s commercial potential, customer segments, and market strategy. Additionally, Phase I garnered external validation through successful competitive awards, including recognition by the prestigious Tools Competition, further underscoring MentorAI’s promise.

Moving forward, Phase II objectives include rigorous randomized controlled trial (RCT) evaluations, deeper integration with additional university systems (e.g., Salesforce CRM), continuous updating and refinement of the AI model, further enhancement of data security compliance (including SOC 2 and GDPR), and development of an open-source, de-identified dataset to advance broader scientific understanding in AI-augmented mentoring.

In summary, NSF’s Phase I investment enabled MentorPRO to develop MentorAI into a secure and highly effective mentoring assistant that addresses critical mentoring program challenges, directly supporting NSF’s broader goals of educational equity, workforce readiness, and innovation in AI-driven educational technology. Our success in Phase I firmly establishes MentorAI’s potential for transformative societal impact through scalable, personalized student support across higher education institutions nationwide.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 05/30/2025
Modified by: Nancy   McNamara
